keyTakeAways: Western sanctions have severely damaged Iran's economy and disproportionately harmed the middle class, which historically drove political reform and stability.
The Iranian middle class—composed of teachers, civil servants, and professionals—has shrunk by 28% between 2012 and 2019 due to sanctions, with 9 million people losing middle-class status.
Sanctions have led to a growing wealth gap: inflation (42.4%) and rising prices of basic goods (e.g., rice) have pushed many into poverty, while the elite prosper in luxury settings.
The middle class is no longer a force for reform; political engagement has shifted from demands for rights to calls for survival and basic economic needs.
Sanctions have weakened independent entrepreneurs and economic actors, strengthening state-linked groups like the IRGC and bonyads, deepening political hardline control.
The perception of inequality is more damaging than actual inequality, contributing to social unrest and weakening national unity.
Iran's middle class, once a century-long achievement through education and opportunity, is now under threat, with long-term recovery requiring generational effort.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Western sanctions on Iran, particularly from 2012 to 2019, have severely undermined the country’s middle class—historically a driving force for political reform, stability, and economic growth. A study using a synthetic control method found that without sanctions, the Iranian middle class would have grown by 17%, but instead, it shrank by 28%, with an estimated 9 million people losing middle-class status. Rising inflation (42.4%), soaring prices of basic goods, and limited access to fuel and employment have pushed millions into poverty, while a small elite benefits from luxury lifestyles. The erosion of the middle class has shifted political engagement from demands for rights and reform to urgent cries for survival, weakening long-term democratic participation. Sanctions have also strengthened state-linked institutions like the IRGC and bonyads, entrenching hardline power. As a result, the Iranian economy remains fragile, and the recovery of the middle class is described as a generational challenge, even if sanctions are lifted.
title: How Western sanctions on Iran have hurt the same middle class that drives reform
